key_points: Joe Biden was safely sworn in as president without any major security incidents.
Security concerns were heightened due to a previous attack by rioters loyal to Donald Trump.
Law enforcement monitored far-right extremist and militia groups for potential threats.
Despite heavy security and the presence of troops, there were only a few scattered arrests and no major protests.
Over 25,000 troops and police were deployed, and the National Mall was closed with extensive checkpoints.
Federal agents were wary of concerning online chatter and possible infiltration attempts.
QAnon followers expressed disappointment online as their conspiracy theories did not materialize.
Twelve National Guard members were removed from their duties due to extremist statements or ties to right-wing militias.
The FBI vetted all 25,000 National Guard members in an unprecedented security effort.
Security in Washington, D.C., is expected to remain heightened for several days post-inauguration.
spokespersons: Gen. Daniel Hokanson (chief, National Guard Bureau)
